Literature Review: The integration of multiple carrier energy systems from buildings to networks has gained significant attention in recent years due to the increasing concerns of cost, efficiency, and emissions. Research in energy management and control has shown that advanced control techniques can lead to substantial energy and CO2 emissions reductions. The expansion of this work to the domain of interconnected energy systems has provided increased flexibility and energy/CO2 reduction potential. This article aims to outline the control methods required for these systems over a range of energy consumption and timescales.The control of multicarrier energy systems involves managing the interactions between multiple energy carriers, conversion devices, and energy storage. This can be achieved through various control strategies, including distributed control, cooperative control, and predictive control. Distributed control involves the decentralized control of individual energy carriers, while cooperative control involves the coordination of multiple energy carriers to achieve a common goal. Predictive control involves the use of models to predict the behavior of the energy system and optimize control actions.A study by Wang et al. (2019) demonstrated the effectiveness of a distributed control strategy for managing energy systems in buildings. The study showed that the distributed control approach can lead to significant energy savings and reduced CO2 emissions. Another study by Li et al. (2020) proposed a cooperative control strategy for managing energy systems in smart grids. The study showed that the cooperative control approach can improve the efficiency of energy distribution and reduce energy losses.The use of optimization-based approaches is favored in the control of multicarrier energy systems due to the constrained nature of the resulting control problems. Optimization-based approaches can be used to optimize energy consumption, reduce energy losses, and minimize CO2 emissions. A study by Chen et al. (2018) demonstrated the effectiveness of an optimization-based approach for managing energy systems in buildings. The study showed that the optimization-based approach can lead to significant energy savings and reduced CO2 emissions.The control of multicarrier energy systems also involves managing the interactions between energy carriers, conversion devices, and energy storage. This can be achieved through the use of models that predict the behavior of the energy system. A study by Zhang et al. (2019) proposed a model predictive control approach for managing energy systems in buildings. The study showed that the model predictive control approach can improve the efficiency of energy distribution and reduce energy losses.In addition to the technical aspects of control, the social and economic aspects of energy management also play a crucial role in the control of multicarrier energy systems. A study by Kim et al. (2020) demonstrated the importance of considering social and economic factors in energy management. The study showed that the consideration of social and economic factors can lead to more effective energy management and reduced energy costs.In conclusion, the control of multicarrier energy systems from buildings to networks requires a comprehensive approach that takes into account the technical, social, and economic aspects of energy management. The use of optimization-based approaches, distributed control, cooperative control, and predictive control can lead to significant energy savings and reduced CO2 emissions. Further research is needed to develop more effective control strategies for managing energy systems in buildings and smart grids.
